results:
Based on the search results, I can provide information about Polish translations of Robinson Crusoe by Daniel Defoe:

## Polish Translations of Robinson Crusoe

The first Polish translation of the novel was commissioned by King Stanisław August Poniatowski and completed by Bishop Jan Chrzciciel Albertrandi, published in 1769 under the title "Przypadki Robinsona Kruzoe". This translation was made from French rather than directly from English, as it was "translated from English to French and shortened by p. Feutry, now published in the native language".

The only complete Polish translation of the novel is the translation of Volume I by Józef Birkenmajer, initially published in 1949. The first volume, in Birkenmajer's translation, is also published as a standalone work.

## Other Polish Adaptations and Versions

The novel is also known in Poland through various adaptations:

In Poland, the novel is also known through adaptations by Władysław Ludwik Anczyc from 1868 titled "Przypadki Robinsona Crusoe" (or "Przypadki Robinsona Kruzoe"), and by Franciszek Mirandola from 1924 titled "Robinson Crusoe. Jego życia losy, doświadczenia i przypadki".

There's also a shortened version edited by Stanisław Stampfl from 1958 titled "Robinson Kruzoe. Według Daniela Defoe napisał Stanisław Stampfl".

The version available on Wolne Lektury (Free Readings) is based on Franciszek Mirandola's translation from 1924, published by Instytut Wydawniczy "Zdrój" in Warsaw.

## Polish Literary Connections

In Poland, Robinson's adventures inspired Czesław Miłosz and Jerzy Andrzejewski, who titled their screenplay based on Władysław Szpilman's memoirs "Robinson warszawski" (from which the film "The Pianist" was later made).

In Polish translations, the character Friday is known as "Piętaszek".

The novel remains a popular classic in Polish literature and is widely available in various editions and formats, including as a free digital text through the Wolne Lektury project.
